Text: We give thanks to You, O God; we give thanks, for Your Name is near. The people declare Your wondrous works.
Context: This is a declaration of gratitude for God's proximity and works, likely a liturgical or worship setting.

Text: When I choose the appointed time, I will judge uprightly.
Context: This is spoken from God's perspective, indicating His sovereignty in choosing when to enact judgment.

Text: When the earth and all its dwellers quake, it is I who bear up its pillars. Selah
Context: This represents God as the sustainer of the earth, the verse reflects on the stability provided by God even when there is turmoil.

Text: I say to the boastful, 'Do not boast,' and to the wicked, 'Do not lift up your horn.
Context: God's admonition against pride and wickedness; "horn" symbolizes strength or power.

Text: Do not lift up your horn on high; do not speak with an outstretched neck.
Context: Further warning against arrogance and haughtiness, using the metaphor of a "stretched neck."

Text: For exaltation comes neither from the east nor the west nor from the desert.
Context: This verse implies that true honor or exaltation does not come from one's geographical location or worldly status.

Text: But it is God who judges; He brings one down, He exalts another.
Context: Emphasizes God's ultimate authority in judging and determining the fates of individuals.

Text: For there is a cup in the hand of the LORD, full of foaming wine mixed with spices; He pours it out, and all the wicked of the earth drain it to the dregs.
Context: The "cup" is a metaphor for God's wrath; the verse speaks of God's judgment upon the wicked.

Text: I will proclaim forever; I will sing praise to the God of Jacob.
Context: This is a declaration of commitment to proclaim and praise God indefinitely; the "anger" is not directed by the psalmist but related to the previous verse's theme of judgment.

Text: All the horns of the wicked will be cut off, but the horns of the righteous will be lifted up.
Context: Contrasts the fate of the wicked with that of the righteous, using the “horn” as a symbol of power and strength.
